entry.title: A Complete Guide To Mobile App Marketing
entry.summary: Standing out among the millions of mobile apps can be challenging, but proper marketing can give you that crucial edge. This piece shares how to start your mobile app marketing strategy and improve it as you go while keeping up with the latest trends in the market.

entry.title: An Introduction To AWS Cloud Development Kit (CDK)
entry.summary: In this article, Vivek Maskara introduces Amazon Web Servicesâ€™ (AWS) Cloud Development Kit (CDK) which is increasingly becoming a popular tool for managing AWS-based infrastructure. Weâ€™ll take a closer look into CDK concepts, and then how to use the AWS CDK toolkit to deploy a sample application to an AWS account.

entry.title: A Guide To Audio Visualization With JavaScript And GSAP (Part 2)
entry.summary: What started as a case study turned into a guide to visualizing audio with JavaScript. Although the output demos are in React, Jhey Tompkins isnâ€™t going to dwell on the React side of things too much. The underlying techniques work with or without React.

entry.title: Performance Signals For Customizing Website UX
entry.summary: Using signals to deliver less, or different, content is a form of progressive enhancement (or graceful degradation depending on how you look at it), whereby extraneous content is only loaded when necessary, but the core functionality of the website still works. In this article, weâ€™ll look at some of the signals that can be used for this.

entry.title: How To Create An Information Architecture That Is Easy To Use
entry.summary: If users cannot find the answers to their questions or are not exposed to critical messaging, they will not act, and your website will fail. To prevent that from happening, you need an effective information architecture. In this article, Paul Boag provides you with a process to ensure you have precisely that.

entry.title: Say Hello to selectmenu, a Fully Style-able select Element
entry.summary: I want to introduce you to a new, experimental form control called <selectmenu>. Weâ€™ll get deep into it, including how much easier it is to style than a traditional <select> element. But first, letâ€™s fill in some context â€¦ Say Hello to selectmenu, a Fully Style-able select Element originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Build Membership Businesses with Memberful
entry.summary: (This is a sponsored post.) What would your business be like if you sold memberships? It might be more than fun to think about, in fact, it might just be transformative. With membership, would you include little add-ons or â€¦ Build Membership Businesses with Memberful originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Building Web Layouts For Dual-Screen And Foldable Devices
entry.summary: Dual-screen devices are just the next evolution in responsive design. If you have a PWA or website, the APIs available make integrating into your existing code base seamless. This article explains why itâ€™s an exciting time for layout on the web, and how dual screens provide an opportunity to get even more creative.

entry.title: 7 Fresh Links on Performance For March 2022
entry.summary: I have a handful of good links to articles about performance that are burning a hole in my bookmarks folder, and wanna drop them here to share. The new WebPageTest website design From fonts to SVG: an icon migration strategy â€¦ 7 Fresh Links on Performance For March 2022 originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: How to Make a â€œRaise the Curtainsâ€ Effect in CSS
entry.summary: â€œRaise the curtainsâ€ is what I call an effect where the background goes from dark to light on scroll, and the content on top also goes from light to dark while in a sticky position. Hereâ€™s an example where I â€¦ How to Make a â€œRaise the Curtainsâ€ Effect in CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: A Guide To Audio Visualization With JavaScript And GSAP (Part 1)
entry.summary: What started as a case study turned into a guide to visualizing audio with JavaScript. Although the output demos are in React, Jhey Tompkins isnâ€™t going to dwell on the React side of things too much. The underlying techniques work with or without React.

entry.title: CSS Custom Highlight API: The Future of Highlighting Text Ranges on the Web
entry.summary: Styling ranges of text in software is a very useful thing to be able to do. Thankfully, we have the CSS Custom Highlight API to look forward to because it represents the future of styling text ranges on the web.â€¦ CSS Custom Highlight API: The Future of Highlighting Text Ranges on the Web originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Ahmad Shadeed: Use Cases For CSS fit-content
entry.summary: Ahmad Shadeed covers the CSS fit-content sizing keyword. Itâ€™s useful! It just doesnâ€™t come up super often. I find myself using min-content a lot more, like when setting up the height of a grid-template-row. The fit-content keyword is actually â€¦ Ahmad Shadeed: Use Cases For CSS fit-content originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: New CSS Features In 2022
entry.summary: 2022 is shaping up to be a pretty great year for CSS, with a plethora of new features on the horizon. Some are already starting to land in browsers, others are likely to gain widespread browser support in 2022, while for one or two the process may be a little longer. In this article weâ€™ll take a look at a few of them.

entry.title: IE Down, Edge Upâ€¦ Global Browser Usage Stats Are for Cocktail Parties and Conference Slides
entry.summary: I enjoy articles like Hartley Charltonâ€™s â€œMicrosoft Edge Looks Set to Overtake Safari as Worldâ€™s Second Most Popular Desktop Browser.â€ Itâ€™s juicy! We know these massive players in the browser market care very much about their market share, so when â€¦ IE Down, Edge Upâ€¦ Global Browser Usage Stats Are for Cocktail Parties and Conference Slides originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: We All Are Ukraine ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¦
entry.summary: As a design community, we all canâ€™t be silent in these times. We need to be united in our fight against the war, for democracy, for those dreams that children are entitled to have when they are growing up. Itâ€™s our obligation to help as much as we can. **We are donating all proceeds** from "Interface Design Checklists" PDF to support Ukraine.

entry.title: Web Component Pseudo-Classes and Pseudo-Elements are Easier Than You Think
entry.summary: Weâ€™ve discussed a lot about the internals of using CSS in this ongoing series on web components, but there are a few special pseudo-elements and pseudo-classes that, like good friends, willingly smell your possibly halitotic breath before you go â€¦ Web Component Pseudo-Classes and Pseudo-Elements are Easier Than You Think originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: March For Equality (2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)
entry.summary: Following our monthly tradition, artists and designers from across the globe challenged their creative skills and designed desktop wallpapers to welcome March. They come in versions with and without a calendar and can be downloaded for free.

entry.title: A Recipe For A Good Design System
entry.summary: Maintaining a design system is a lot of work. In this article, Atila Fassina shares his lessons learned and how a platform such as Backlight can help put together a series of tools to speed up your architecture setup.

entry.title: Trailing Slashes on URLs: Contentious or Settled?
entry.summary: A fun deep dive from Zach. Do you have an opinion on which you should use? 1) https://website.com/foo/ 2) https://websites.com/foo The first option has a â€œtrailing slash.â€ The second does not. Iâ€™ve always preferred this thinking: you use a trailing â€¦ Trailing Slashes on URLs: Contentious or Settled? originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: When to Avoid the text-decoration Shorthand Property
entry.summary: In my recent article about CSS underline bugs in Chrome, I discussed text-decoration-thickness and text-underline-offset, two relatively new and widely-supported CSS properties that give us more control over the styling of underlines. Let me demonstrate the usefulness of â€¦ When to Avoid the text-decoration Shorthand Property originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Manuel Matuzovicâ€™s CSS Specificity Demo
entry.summary: If youâ€™re looking for a primer on CSS specificity, weâ€™ve got that. And if youâ€™re trying to get ahead of the game, you should be aware of CSS Cascade Layers as well. One of the ways to help get â€¦ Manuel Matuzovicâ€™s CSS Specificity Demo originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: My white whale: A use case for will-change
entry.summary: Nic Chan: [â€¦] theÂ will-changeÂ property landed in major browsers in August 2015, and Iâ€™ve been on the lookout for when to use it ever since. It might seem self-evident to apply it to commonly animated properties such â€¦ My white whale: A use case for will-change originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Explain the First 10 Lines of Twitterâ€™s Source Code to Me
entry.summary: For the past few weeks, Iâ€™ve been hiring for a senior full-stack JavaScript engineer at my rental furniture company, Pabio. Since weâ€™re a remote team, we conduct our interviews on Zoom, and Iâ€™ve observed that some developers are not â€¦ Explain the First 10 Lines of Twitterâ€™s Source Code to Me originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: How To Benchmark And Improve Web Vitals With Real User Metrics
entry.summary: Web Vitals are the new gold standard in performance due to their direct correlation with the userâ€™s experience. In this article, youâ€™ll learn what monitoring can do and how RayGun can help you sustain performance maintenance while scaling your app.

entry.title: Using The WordPress Editor And CPTs To Configure Plugins
entry.summary: If we want our WordPress plugins to offer a settings page that is fully powered by blocks, how can we do it? Since *Full Site Editing* doesnâ€™t support this feature yet, we need to code a custom solution. In this article, we will learn how we can do it.

entry.title: How To Develop A Text Editor For The Web
entry.summary: How do text typing and editing work on the web? Although this process might seem straightforward, there is a lot of technical nuance behind its apparent simplicity. This article looks at how typing on the web works.

entry.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 45 With Jeremy Wagner: What Is Responsible JavaScript?
entry.summary: In this episode, weâ€™re talking about Responsible JavaScript. What does it mean for code to be responsible, and how should we approach projects differently? Drew McLellan talks to expert Jeremy Wagner to find out.

entry.title: Testing Pipeline 101 For Frontend Testing
entry.summary: You donâ€™t need to be a full DevOps engineer if you want to introduce a testing build routine. With the help of some testing frameworks and GitHub actions, Ramona Schwering gives a short kick-off to help you get on the right track.
